key_insight: GerNA-Bind uses geometric deep learning to model multistate RNA–ligand interactions, enabling accurate prediction of binding specificity by explicitly accounting for RNA conformational variability and ligand geometry.
problem_solved: Predicting RNA–ligand binding specificity is hard because RNA adopts multiple conformations and interactions are geometry-dependent; existing methods struggle to capture multistate structural context and fine-grained spatial features needed for reliable predictions.
method: Encode RNA and ligands as geometry-aware graphs that capture 3D structure and multistate conformations.
Apply geometric (structure‑equivariant) message-passing neural networks to learn interaction-aware embeddings across RNA states and ligand poses.
Train and evaluate on curated RNA–ligand datasets to predict binding specificity and discriminate binders from non-binders.
impact: Provides a principled, structure-aware modeling approach that improves prediction of RNA–ligand specificity, accelerating target discovery and rational design workflows for RNA-targeting therapeutics and chemical probes.
visual_elements: Schematic of multistate RNA conformations with the same ligand binding different pockets/states
Model architecture diagram showing geometry-aware graph construction and equivariant message passing between RNA and ligand nodes
Performance chart comparing GerNA-Bind to baseline methods (ROC/PR or accuracy gains)
Heatmap or 3D overlay highlighting predicted binding specificity across RNA residues/ligand chemotypes
paper_title: Deciphering RNA–ligand binding specificity with GerNA-Bind
paper_authors: Yunpeng Xia, Jiayi Li, Yi-Ting Chu, Jiahua Rao, Jing Chen
